metadata.case_name: Gurdit Singh v. Mst. Angrez Kaur

facts.text: Sunder Singh executed a will on 4th November, 1950, in favour of his niece, Udham Kaur.

On 27th October, 1951, Tarlok Singh executed a document divorcing his wife, Mst. Angrez Kaur (respondent No. 1), on the ground that she frequently went away from his house without his consent and became furious when enquired.
Mst. Angrez Kaur claims that after divorce by Tarlok Singh, she was married to Sunder Singh by custom known as Chadar Andazi.
On 7th June, 1952, Sunder Singh revoked his previous will, acknowledged Mst. Angrez Kaur as his wife and left the property to her.
Appellant Gurdit Singh, collateral of Sunder Singh in third degree, applied for mutation of property.
On 12th December, 1954, mutation sanctioned in favour of Gurdit Singh.
Mst. Angrez Kaur filed suit on 17th March, 1955, claiming property as widow of Sunder Singh.
Trial Court decreed suit, holding marriage by Chadar Andazi valid.
On appeal, Additional District Judge set aside decree, held marriage invalid as during lifetime of first husband, no custom justified.

Punjab High Court remitted issue on custom to trial court: 'Is there any custom amongst the tribes of the parties according to which the divorce given by Tarlok Singh to Mst. Angrez Kaur is recognised enabling her to enter into a valid marriage by Chadar Andazi with Sunder Singh?'
Trial Court, after further evidence, answered issue in negative; District Judge endorsed.
High Court held custom proved and decreed suit.
Parties are Jats from Jullundur District.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1, Mst. Angrez Kaur, proved existence of custom in community allowing Tarlok Singh to divorce her, enabling valid Chadar Andazi marriage with Sunder Singh while first husband alive.

petitioner_arguments.text: No such custom exists amongst Jats in Jullundur District; relied on Rattigan's Digest of Customary Law (paras 72,74,75) stating Hindus cannot divorce without special custom, and woman cannot marry second husband while first alive.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rattigan's Digest of Customary Law, 14th Ed., para 72,74,75; Riwaj-i-am of Jullundur 1885 and 1914-15

petitioner_arguments.text: Riwaj-i-am of Jullundur reliable, states no divorce among Hindus except Kambohs of Nakodar Tahsil.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kunwar Basant Singh v. Kinwar Brij Rai-Saran Singh; Mahant Salig Ram v. Musammat Maya Devi

petitioner_arguments.text: Custom primarily tribal but local; no uniform custom; doubted in Jullundur.

respondent_arguments.text: Custom exists allowing divorce by husband and valid second marriage by Chadar Andazi even if first husband alive; proved by Riwaj-i-am of neighbouring districts and witness statements with instances.

court_reasoning.text: Rattigan's Digest recognizes special customs for Hindus including Jats; leaves open possibility in Jullundur; notices customs in surrounding districts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rattigan of little help as doubts custom in Jullundur.

court_reasoning.text: Riwaj-i-am of Jullundur unreliable per precedents; not carefully prepared; contradicted by evidence.
Appellant's witnesses admitted custom allowing Hindu Jat husband to divorce wife (verbally or writing), though qualified no second marriage during lifetime.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witnesses: Bhag Singh, Karam Singh, Kartar Singh, Ujagar Singh, Niranjan Singh, Gurdit Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Custom of divorce dissolves marriage; no reason divorced wife cannot remarry; incongruous to allow divorce but not remarriage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent witnesses and instances prove full custom including valid second marriage.

court_reasoning.text: Neighbouring districts' Riwaj-i-am relevant as custom tribal.

holdings.text: Custom proved allowing divorce by Hindu Jat husband in Jullundur and valid Chadar Andazi second marriage even during lifetime of first husband.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kunwar Basant Singh v. Kinwar Brij Rai-Saran Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Value of Riwaj-i-am as evidence of customary law.
Riwaj-i-am admissible, statements accepted even unsupported.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahant Salig Ram v. Musammat Maya Devi
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption of correctness of Riwaj-i-am entries; rebuttable; unreliable if not carefully prepared.
Riwaj-i-am presumptive evidence if reliable, carefully prepared, no contradictions.
Jullundur Riwaj-i-am unreliable, not prepared with care.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court decree upheld; custom of divorce and valid second marriage by Chadar Andazi proved; Mst. Angrez Kaur entitled to property as widow of Sunder Singh.
outcome.relief_granted: Suit decreed in favour of respondent No. 1

key_quotes.text: "Custom in the Punjab is primarily tribal and not local, though the custom of a particular tribe may and often does differ in particular localities."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis for inferring custom from neighbouring districts.

key_quotes.text: "It seems to be clear that there is no uniform custom applicable to the whole of the Punjab. Custom varies from time to time and from place to place."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "On the dissolution of such a marriage, there seems to be no reason why the divorced wife cannot marry a second husband in the life-time of her first husband."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding extending divorce custom to valid remarriage.
